title: FIFA World Cup Trophy with text
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Occasionally we hold FIFA 2012 tournaments and I wanted something that the current winner can keep until he/she is dethroned.  You can print out the STL with just the FIFA World Cup text or use the openscad file to create your own text.  In this case I am giving the trophy as a birthday present and so I've added 'SMITH LEAGUE' onto the back.

Based on drayde's FIFA World Cup in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3494 . You willneed to download the fifa.stl from there. I just used br3ttb's smallsidefont.scad to add the FIFA World Cup text. Additionally, you can add text onto the backside for fun. Be sure to use the 'font' spreadsheet in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12618 to get the text spaced correctly. Print height is 95mm but you can change that with the scale feature in openscad.

The ESP 01 Board (based on the ESP 8266) is tiny and cheap and a really good way to add WiFi capabilities to your project, however, it is also not solderless-breadboard friendly.

This is a small connector that fits the ESP 01 board and is easy to connect.

The smaller part is the top, insert your wires into the little grooves at the top, then press the ESP01 into the holes on top of them.

You can use the connector standalone when you just need the ESP 01 or you can use it as a part of a bigger project.

The top is designed to fit into a hole in a lid of a box, the narrower part fits into the hole and the lid covers the wider part and holds the wires in place.

I've included the SkethUp file so you can easily use it in your own designs.

Designed with SketchUp, STL cleaned with Microsoft 3D Builder, sliced with Cura and printed on my Robo3D R1+

The ESP 01 (ESP 8266 based) is a very nice tiny WiFi-enabled board, it's extreamly useful, especially if you upload new firmware into it.

However, it is not solderless-breadboard friendly and requires connecting and disconnecting wires to switch between normal and flash modes.

So, I designed this little box that does all this for you, one side conencts to 3.3V power, the other to your PC using a serial adapter and in the middle you plug your ESP 01 board, the design is based on my previous ESP 01 Connector

This box features a switch to select normal or falsh mode, a reset button and a little bump on top that doesn't let you plug in your ESP module up side down.

Parts:

  • A toggle switch (I used "New original 10pcs 3-Pin SPDT ON-ON Toggle Switch 6A 125VAC" from AliExpress)
  • A push button, 6x6x3mm size

The switch fits into the round hole on one side, the push button sits it the small cradle on the other side, see picture with wiring instractions.

Note that:

  1. You may need to connect the switch diffrently depending on the model of your spacific switch (the wires need to be connected in flash mode and disconnected in run mode)
  2. The TX/RX labels match the ones on the ESP, you need to connect RX on the box to TX on your serial adaptor and vice versa

Designed with SketchUp, STL cleaned up with Microsoft 3D Builder, sliced with Cura and printed on a Robo3D R1+

title: Safety Magazine - BSA and Gamo PCP

description.text:
A Magazine blank, ideally printed in a bright non-matching colour to indicate it's installation and prevent a loaded mag fed BSA PCP. It was designed as a safety indicator as well as a device preventing debris from entering the rifle when unloaded during transport.

There are three versions, BSA Safety is a through hole version, allowing complete closure of the bolt. The blind version has a bolt rest, but doesn't allow the pellet probe to enter the breech. The NEW Bolt Closed version allows you to keep the bolt close to insert / remove the keeper.

The pellet probe hole is over size to allow all calibres of BSA and Gamo air rifles to utilise this safety device.
All measurements taken from Mk1 and latest generation .177 magazines.

description.text: Character design to be etched.  I have not tested this design at all.

This is a one-piece design for the Mendel X motor bracket. The clamps are all built-in. All M4 nuts are captive where possible, and only two idlers are provided for the X axis belt to run over. Additionally, there are two loops positioned so that a 50mm PC cooling fan can be used to cool the X motor. This may be necessary if you're hunting for speed and making the X motor a trifle warm!

It's mostly parametric so you can fiddle with rail spacing to make it fit a Darwin chassis etc.
This part also does away with the need for X Motor Spacers. A small notch in the end of the bracket rests directly on the Z Guide Rail and constrains it.

Letzte und Finale Version meiner Schutzhülle.

print_settings.Notes:: The mount should be printed with the large end on the build plate and with supports. The body and firing pin button should also be printed upright. I made mine in PLA and it works well.

description.text:
"The Parasite" - it attaches to the side of a larger object and can be rather unfriendly. This one is for airsoft use, and I keep one attached when going to CQB games. It is made to use PPS gas shells, so similar sized shells such as Madbull and Dytac should work as well.

Only four parts to be printed. The only other part(s) needed are 1) an appropriate spring for the firing pin button, but it will fit 4 ballpoint pen springs if needed; and 2) a pair of 6mm dia. x 2mm magnets to assist in keeping the barrel closed, although I haven't found these necessary in my games.

To assemble, rotate the body onto the mount and put the small tab in the slot. Slide the mount onto the picatinny rail where it will live. Insert the firing pin spring(s) & button and push in as you slide the rear plate in. This slides down over the button and locks the mount onto the rail. Done.

NOTE: Do NOT attempt to load real shotgun shells into this as it probably won't fire, and if it does it will likely cause serious personal injury or death. Don't even try it. Also, if you are in the U.S., it would probably be advisable to print the body in that horrid orange as required by law.

Printer:

Wanhao i3 v2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

The mount should be printed with the large end on the build plate and with supports. The body and firing pin button should also be printed upright. I made mine in PLA and it works well.

This is an enclosure for supercapacitor (AKA ultracapacitors) or similar battery cell shaped objects. It was made with OpenSCAD and is a work in progress. It can be customized and scaled. This is my first project and I am still working to improve the structure.

The lid for the this project is available at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1730028

Git project available at: https://github.com/jetpack-maniac/Supercapacitor-Enclosure

THERE IS ONE KNOWN BUG. It's listed on Github. The screw holes placed into the center posts don't always get added to shapes that are longer than they are wide. I am investigating the cause.

The code can be modified to suit various configuration and sizes of components. The default is a 2x3 grid of D cell capacitors. I created this to install an automotive supercapacitor bank to replace the lead-acid battery for car charging.

Design Philosophy:

I wanted an enclosure with enough space to store the cells plus the protection circuits. I also cutaway at the area between the cells providing enough space to hold them safely and securely. The center posts have been tapped to allow mounting of various things (in my config I'll be placing the over-voltage protection circuit of which I'll post when it's complete).

The lid has two large bolt holes of which I'll be using some kind of bolt as the electrodes to attach this. My previous case has wire right next to each other coming out soldered to battery lugs and those were a nightmare. Constantly touching each other when not in use.

This is a prototype and I will be printing my first two cases this week and updating them based on my experience with them. Stay tuned for the cap circuits and the final install and performance of the devices.

The code can be modified to suit various configuration and sizes of components. The default is a 2x3 grid of D cell capacitors. I created this to install an automotive supercapacitor bank to replace the lead-acid battery for car charging.

The two large holes are for the electrodes or wires to come out of the case. In my case I will be using bolts. See the enclosure link above or github project for the most up to date information.

title: Space-filling molecular models: Halogen expansion set

description.text:
The halogens are one of the best reasons for using space-filling models. With ball-and-stick models and especially writing structures on paper, you can easily convince yourself that all the atoms are about the same size. With most of the halogens, this decidedly doesn't apply. Most of them are several times larger than carbon or nitrogen. Granted they are further down the periodic table so you would expect them to be larger, but it's still surprising how much larger they are. "Are they really that weird shape?" I hear you ask. Probably not; we don't know exactly what they look like. They are probably more spherical, but they can crowd nearby atoms so some allowances are made. "I thought one of the points of space-filling models was to tell when things get too close together." True, but they don't crowd other atoms that much, and atomic orbitals seem to be more compliant than ABS (it would be interesting to try using flexible filament). Bromine is traditionally brown but I didn't have any brown filament (and I think I like it in gold).

See the starter set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1720048), carbon expansion set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1730299), nitrogen expansion set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1753583), aromatic expansion set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1754393), and the sulfur and phosphorous expansion set (http://thingaverse.com/thing:2350618) for more useful elements.

description.text:
Motivation

I am designing a new printer from scratch and I'm sharing it here so everyone can customize and build his own version of this. The idea is to make a printer with "big" build room without being "too huge" itself, and it needs to be fast, precise and affordable.

Plan

The non-sucking 3D printer (NS3DP) is a cartesian printer with the bed moving in Z-direction and the print head moving in XY-direction. For the electronics, I chose the RAMPS 1.4 with the graphical display/SD module. It uses E3D Titan Extruders with pancake 13Ncm steppers for a lightweight print head. As much as possible will be 3D printed parts to keep the price low - as long as it doesn't affect print quality.

Details

The frame is made of 40mm aluminium profiles. Optional diagonals can be used to make it even more sturdy if the build volume gets big.

I decided to use ultimaker-style movement mechanics for the print head's XY-movement (meaning there are no belts or spindles attached to the print head directly). I doubled the "cross-hair" axis, for less ringing during fast accelerations. But unlike the ultimaker, this printer does not use the linear rods as rotating axis, so linear ball bearings can be used, too. In Z-direction, four spindles will drive the heavy heated bed. If your printer has a lighter print bed, you might get away with two.

Update (2018-01-21)

I removed the "work in progress" marker as the printer is in a working state with acceptable quality. There will be future improvements (the electronics will get their own PCB, the print head will get a redesign and the vertical sliders will get ball bearings instead of the igus bearings), but for now, it is a working printer.

Printer:

Velleman K8200

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15-30%

Notes:

Printed with E3D Edge on clean glass. Superb adhesion and layer bonding. Many but not all parts need supports, depends on your printer. Keep in mind the orientation sometimes helps. Some parts of the print head are for example better printed upside-down. Most parts are designed in the best printing orientation already though.

If you are using Simplify3D for slicing, you can save a lot of unnecessary material with these settings:

  • supports: 10-15% and 10 dense support layers of 30% on top
  • infill: 15% full honeycomb and parts with higher strength requirements like the printer's feet or the print bed corner holders' overhanging part in a separate process with 30% full honeycomb

Non-printed parts needed for assembly of this 40x40x20mm print volume build from the pictures

40x40 profiles with 8mm slot from motedis.com

  • 4x 280mm for the vertical bars in z direction
  • 4x 500mm for the horizontal bars in y direction
  • 4x 580mm for the horizontal bars in x direction
  • 132 matching cage nuts for M5 screws

20x20 profiles with 5mm slot from motedis.com

  • 4x 540mm for the top rails on the rail holder corners
  • 2x 360mm for the print bed holder bars in x direction
  • 2x 400mm for the print bed holder bars in y direction
  • 28 matching cage nuts for M5 screws

12mm precision linear rods from motedis.com

  • 4x 340mm for vertical guides
  • 4x 570mm for horizontal outer rails
  • 4x 500mm for horizontal "cross" connecting the print head to the outer sliders

from igus.de

  • 4x 340mm TR14x4 trapezoidal with matching flange nut and 20mm long, 8mm wide blank shaft at the end (those 20mm are within the total length of the trapezoidal, just to be clear)
  • 4x standard ball bearing ID=8mm, OD=22mm

from e3d-online.com

  • 2x Titan Extruders (not mirrored, standard version)
  • 1x chimera hot-end

from omc-stepperonline.com

  • 4x NEMA17 1,8 deg 45 Ncm for the Z axis
  • 2x NEMA17 1,8 deg 65 Ncm for the X and Y axis
  • 2x NEMA17 1,8 deg 18 Ncm for the extruders

from the hardware store, your local electronics store or somewhere on the internet

  • M5 screws and nuts of various lengths for everything that is screwed
  • 4m of GT2 6mm belts
  • 2x GT2 pulleys for 5mm axles
  • 4x precision shaft connectors 5mm to 8mm
  • 20x 12mm linear bearings type LM12UU (ID=12mm, OD=22mm, length=32mm)
  • 13x ball bearing ID=5mm OD=16mm height=5mm
  • 2x 40mm fans for the extruder, ones with static pressure and not just airflow
  • 1x RAMPS 1.4
  • 8x DRV8825 stepper drivers
  • 1x PSU 12V/100W for the RAMPS
  • 1x FilaFarm BoroBase 40x40mm 230V heated bed
Printed parts needed for assembly
  • 24x "corner" or "corner with diagonal" (diagonals are a good idea for a printer larger than 50x50cm volume, add them to bottom, sides and back)
  • 1x each of the four "rail holder corners"
  • 6x "rail holder corner end cap"
  • 5x "idler (plain)"
  • 8x "idler (gt2)"
  • 2x "xy axis slider high belt"
  • 2x "xy axis slider low belt"
  • 4x "spindle holder top"
  • 4x "spindle holder bottom"
  • 4x "spindle motor holder"
  • 4x "z axis slider"
  • 4x "z axis slider bearing base" - two of them mirrored (sorry, forgot to make a mirrored one)
  • 4x "z axis slider bearing cap"
  • 4x "foot ikea lack" OR "foot" plus silicone molded inserts made using "foot mold cup" and "foot mold insert" OR the experimental ball foot made of three parts
  • 4x "print bed holder corner"
  • 1x "print head center part"
  • 1x "print head bottom funnel" (one side attached with screws, the other one with wire)
  • 4x "print head bearing cuffs lm12uu"
  • 1x "arduino mega holder"
  • 1x "psu holder"
  • 2x "xy axis slider external spacer", scaled to the right height for your build so the endstops trigger near the corner of the print bed
  • 6x "xy slider belt clamp base"
  • 6x "xy slider belt clamp"
  • some M5 washers as needed for spacing the idlers
Building the printer

Make sure to position all parts at the correct place (their names tell their positions in most cases).

The two belts are routed in a shape like the outline of the character "U". The high belt "U" is seen from the front, the low belt "U" is seen from the right.

Mount gt2-idlers in the far corners of each rail holder corner, a stack of two each. Mount plain idlers in the near corners of each rail holder corner, a stack of two in the front right, only the high one on the front left and only the low one in the rear corners.

Put the open ends of the high belt on the left XY slider's outside and the open ends of the low belt on the rear XY slider's outside. Fix the belts with another single belt clamp to the opposite side of the printer's XY slider on the inside.

The rest should be relatively obvious, I hope.

Dimensions

I wanted it big, but not huge. So I had a look at the prices and found out the most expensive part was the print bed. This limited the XY-size, I added a little extra height, so the inner size of the printer is 50x50x60cm minus the space for trapezoidals, print head size and so on it will come out at around 36x38x55cm actually printable size, I guess. (Update: I shortened it, now the print size is 36x36x20cm, makes it easier to transport the printer)

At that size, I wanted a sturdy frame, so I went for the biggest aluminium profiles that didn't look "too" bulky. And I wanted diagonals which had to be half the thickness so they fit in the frame and don't overhang. 40mm and 20mm, it was. (Update: with the shorter size, diagonals are no longer necessary, so I removed them again)

Frame

I started with a plain corner. Two bolts into each aluminium profiles, sturdy enough so it doesn't bend or break easily, a design that can be printed without supports, that was the idea. Looks "almost" good without supports on my cheap printer.

Next, I modified the corner to get a diagonal for reinforcing the frame. Done with the frame, next step.

Movement on XY-Axis

For the XY-movement, I chose linear rods on top of the frame's aluminium profiles and belts to move them. Each belt goes 3/4 around the frame, so there's a lot of idlers involved, some with teeth, some without.

I started with one corner, mirrored it for the second one, then took these two and added motor mounts and additional holes and rollers where needed to get the belt to the motors.

For the corners to be successfully mounted, the linear rods have to be away, so I needed holes to push them in through afterwards and end caps to keep them there. Funny when two corners are printed and can't be mounted because I forgot the hole!

After tightening the belts, I found out the massive plastic corners bent a lot. Time for a redesign with an extra rail of aluminium on top.

Movement on Z-Axis

For the Z-movement, I chose linear rods again for being way cheaper than linear rails but getting the same precision. The Z-axis is driven by trapezoidal spindles, I chose TR14x4 spindles from Igus.

The goal here was to use as little space between the printer frame and the print bed as possible and to support all four corners as near to the corners as possible. For the top bearing, I added a dual extrusion version where you can print the mount in the material of your choice (ABS, Edge, PLA, ...) and the bearing part with Iglidur from Igus for extra durability.

The part connecting an aluminium frame to the print bed was a little tricky because the print bed mount was designed to be screwed from below, but the place the screw would go is needed for the frame. The result needs some supports to print but works surprisingly well.

Print Head

The print head must be as lightweight as possible while being sturdy enough so it doesn't bend or rattle. I designed it around Igus linear bearings and an E3D Chimera hotend. So the linear rods must give enough space to fit the hotend in between and for proper cooling, some cooling vents had to be added, too.

Again, this thing needs to be assembled in order to get the bearings in, so it's several parts that are printed separately.

Physical Auto Bed Leveling

After many test prints, I noticed the Z trapezoidal spindles not being perfectly at the same height anymore. This is due to the stepper drivers deactivating and activating. After activation, they start on their default phase which isn't necessarily the phase the stepper motor is currently at. So they randomly jump a step left or right on activation.

To fix this, I added four Z endstops and a little 74xx TTL logic that interrupts the STEP signal for each individual Z axis stepper if the direction is UP and its endstop is reached. Once all four endstops are triggered, the "endstop triggered" signal is then sent back to the RAMPS. This way, any time the Z axis homes to the 0 position, it automatically levels and the error with Z steppers not running in sync anymore is recalibrated to fit.

The formulas for the logic chips:
step_motor = ((direction_up AND NOT endstop_x) OR direction_down) AND step_ramps
endstop_ramps = endstop_a AND endstop_b AND endstop_c AND endstop_d

comments.text: As far as I know, "CoreXY" only applies to printers where the belts of at least one axis are directly connected to the print head. I could be wrong there though. Your design involves idlers on moving parts which I didn't want. I also wanted one motor to move one axis only to avoid possible crosstalk and difficulties on calibrating for exactly perpendicular movement.
comments.author: Prot0typ1cal

comments.text: AFAIK, all core XY machines use idlers on the Y, and attached on the X. I simply moved the X out board into the blocks that drive the X rods in my sketch. No need to be connected to the head, just convenient on a H-Bot.
comments.author: markusbart

comments.text: How do I want to drive X and Y... take the character "U" with a very bold font. Now draw only the outline of it, not filled. This outline is the shape of the closed-loop belt I will be using. On the right vertical bar of the "U", the the outer outline is used, on the left vertical bar of the "U", the inner outline is used. So both used parts of the belt always move in the same direction (up or down on the "U"). Connect both sides of the beam to these two parts of the belt and it is moved in the same direction on both ends.
comments.author: Prot0typ1cal

comments.text: Thanks, the "U" makes perfect sense.
comments.author: markusbart

comments.text: I'm not sure how good the "U" shape will actually work - it is simple and lightweight, so much is true. If I don't mess up the gliders on the axis along the frame's edges, the printer should be able to go much faster and produce better quality prints than my heavily modified Velleman K8200. At over 10 times the build volume. So much for the crazy plan :)

title: Combined Layered Drop-Down Longboard
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Combined Layered Drop-Down Longboard

This sectional drop-down longboard design is based on the concept I’ve described in the article http://www.townscooter.com/p/combined-drop-down-longboard.html
It is a drop-down longboard that can be made without veneer pressing. You only need to cut parts using CNC router or laser cutter or even electric jigsaw and then assemble them.

Materials

I recommend the Baltic birch plywood to make this longboard. Nose and Tail parts can be made of 9 ply (12mm) plywood. The main platform should be made of 11 ply (15mm) plywood for a 70-110 kg rider or 9 ply (12mm) plywood for a less than 70 kg rider.

Notes

  • You only need the Combined Layered Drop-down Longboard.DXF file to make parts of the longboard. 3D model files (.123D, .STP) are provided for references.
  • The main platform sizes are suitable for trucks with more than 2” wheelbase offset, e.g. Randal trucks. If you use shorter offset trucks, e.g. Paris or Slant trucks, it may require to extend wheel cutouts on the main platform.
  • Truck cutouts on the main platform probably should be extended to suit your trucks sizes.
  • You do not need to drill all holes on the nose and tail part. You can drill holes for the new school or the old school mounting. It depends on your trucks model.
  • You should put washers between the nose and tail parts and the main platform on the inner bolts. For the minimal drop, washer’s height should be about the height of trucks baseplate. You can increase drop level using risers or washers on the inner truck bolts and inner platform bolts.

Licensing

This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

Please refer to http://www.townscooter.com/ for more information

remixed_from.author: MeisnerX
remixed_from.title: Sunhokey Right Side Bowden Extruder Mount

description.text:
• Updated 20160909: Adjusted the motor holder to the right about 5mm to provide better clearance at maximum Z heights. The first design touched the acrylic. RevF is the newer one (orange in the photos).

I first saw MeisnerX's idea to shorten the Bowden tube in early July 2016, and started making mods to fit my rig as I have had time to work on it. This is my current version as of late August 2016. I see that MeisnerX has changed his design significantly from his original mounting method on his latest revision, but here is my version, an offshoot of his original design.
Similar to his original design, I still mount off the main X axis rods, but flipped the design to move the motor more to the front of the printer.

I left the motor mount opening large to allow more air flow around different motors, and added 4 of the 3mmx25mm bolts with 3mm nuts and springs to hold the motor in place. I also added some little clamp pads to stop the screws from marking the stepper motor.

I have found that feeding the filament form the bottom or top of the spool depends on the size and weight of the spool. Both ways seem to work fine.

I have made several mods to my Sunhokey Prusa i3, the one that you see here is the Compact Bowden Extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:669459) printed in yellow.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Sunhokey Prusa i3 (modified)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layers

Infill:

25% seems fine

Notes:

Filament Used: Hobby King 1.75mm PLA (Red)

Hobby King Orange Translucent 1.75mm PLA

Modeler: Rhino3D

Slicer: Simplify3D

Controller: OctoPrint

I accidentally printed the orange one (RevF) with supports on which resulted in a lot of picking out support material. Supports should not be required.
I drilled out the holes a bit to mount to the horizontal rods, and to make sure that the 3mm bolts fit properly. Nothing else that I recall.

title: GEEETech i3C (METAL version): Dual Extruder FAN & LED
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hi,
now GEEETech proposes the Acrylic Prusa I3 pro series, B for single extruder and C for dual extruder, with metallic parts instead of original printer ones.
Quite immediately I’ve ordered the upgrade kit in order to improve the stability and the quality of my, already not-so-bad printer, unfortunately the customization I’ve designed for the plastic version of this printer cannot be used on the metal one, so I’ve started designing a completely new customization, starting with all lesson learned from my original customization!
One, main, lesson learned was to decouple all contact, in order to enable easy mounting, maintenance and upgrade!
Here the Dual Extruder FAN & LED component of my new customization!
In this design you can find place to put ties in order keep in position all cables, as you can see in my photos!
For FAN Duct you can find closed & open version, I prefer closed one but I know that lot of people can love open version!

As usual in all my design I’ve split all in order to have an easy print of each, and also an easy mounting after print!
PS: after the installation of this customization is a good Idea to re-execute the PID Autotest… I’ve do two time, one with fan power off and one with fan power on, and both was really different from the same test executed just couple hours before!

IF YOU “FALL IN LOVE” OF THIS DESIGN, PLEASE, REMEMBER THAT IT TAKE TIME TO BE CREATED, DESIGNED AND SHARED… SO “MAYBE” YOU CAN USE THE “TIP DESIGNED” BUTTON ON MY PROFILE!

title: Space-filling molecular models: Carbon expansion set

description.text:
Carbon generally can make four bonds to other atoms. If there is only one bond to each atom, the carbon resembles a tetrahedron with an atom bound to each face (or vertex, depending on how you're drawing it). If there is a double bond, the atoms generally occupy the same plane and are 120 degrees from one another. If there is a triple bond, the atoms are in a straight line. So here I present the carbon atoms for the multiply bonded atoms. I designed CarbonDB2 for when you have two carbon atoms double-bonded together. When you have a double bond with bulky side groups on the same side as the bond (the "cis" side in chemspeak) sometimes the angle between the singly bonded atoms relaxes, generally to around 110 degrees. In that case use CarbonDBR. If you have carbon double-bonded to any other atom (generally oxygen or nitrogen) use CarbonDB3. It's exactly the same as CarbonDB2, but the edges are relaxed a bit so it looks better (I'm not exactly sure what these atoms actually look like, but I'm pretty sure they don't have edges). Use whichever one you like. You may have noticed for most of the atoms I've provided that you can rotate the atoms about the bond. You can't do that for the double bonded ones though, because they are locked in place (just like real atoms). The rectangular socket is for the double bond, it represents a slightly smaller bond distance than the other two. CarbonTB3 is for triple-bonded carbon. Technically, you can't rotate those either, but since you can only bond them to another carbon or nitrogen, resulting in something completely symmetrical, no one can tell you can't rotate it so I didn't bother locking it. What looks very much like a triple bond though is a cumulative double bond; in that case you have two groups end-to-end locked at right angles. Use CarbonCDB1 for that. "That doesn't sound like something I'll ever have to make" I hear you exclaim. Yes, you may think so, but this is the carbon you use for carbon dioxide; which is symmetrical, and boring. "You should get out more." Yes, my wife says the same thing.

On another note, space filling models are based on two measurements; the covalent radius, which is the distance between atoms. and the Van der Waals radius, which gives the diameter of the atom itself. The covalent radii can be calculated quite accurately; the Van der Waals radii are harder. There are several values for the Van der Waals radius for carbon; I use a value of 1.5 Angstroms, which is a little on the small size (some use 1.7). I think it looks better. Perhaps this shouldn't be the first criterion to be considered, but it shouldn't be the last either.

As a bonus, this set includes double-bonded oxygen. See the starter set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1720048), halogen expansion set (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1730099), and the sulfur and phosphorous expansion set (http://thingaverse.com/thing:2350618) for more useful elements.

title: Flashforge Creator Pro See Through Filament Guide

description.text:
Tired of having to peek behind your Flashforge Creator Pro to check the colors of the filaments currently loaded? Well, you are in luck. This thing will allow you to see the filament colors while looking at your printer from the front. As a bonus, you will also have better visual feedback while loading a new filament into the filament guides.

To build this thing, all you need to do is getting a clear PTFE tube with 4mm inner diameter and 6mm outer diameter (sometimes called 4X6mm or just 4X6), cut it with the sharp knife to the same length as the existing tube and insert it instead.

Those clear tubes are available on ebay from several vendors and cost a few bucks. Search for 'clear PTFE tube' or something like that.

My science nerd friend tells me that there is no such thing as clear PTFE and that clear material is probably FEP (Fluorinated Ethylene Propylene) but my 3D printer doesn't know it and works just the same.

print_settings.Notes:: A very straightforward print. I used "dishwasher safe" high-temp black PLA. It should be a little tight, so work a lens in the mount a bit before attaching to a camera -- that way, you can clean any little shards that the flange might cut the first time you fit a lens to it. The bayonet wings are designed to print in the given orientation without supports or post processing. There are three files. Just printing a_20160820.stl will give you the adapter body and two copies of the rather small lens locking pin (one and a spare). Alternatively, the adapter body by itself is a_20160820adapter.stl and a_20160820lockpin.stl is the lens locking pin.

title: Minolta/Konica-Minolta/Sony A Lens To Leica M Body (Techart Pro LM-EA7) Adapter

description.text:
In 1985, Minolta became the first company to produce a body-driven autofocus 35mm SLR -- the Maxxum 7000 -- and with it, the new A (also called Alpha or AF, replacing the incompatible manual-focus SR/MC/MD) mount became the camera system to have. Unfortunately, lawsuits soon followed: Exxon sued over the typography of "xx" in Maxxum and Honeywell (Pentax) sued claiming the autofocus technology infringed on their patents. It's a long story, but that began a slow fade; Minolta became Konica Minolta in 2003, finally giving their camera business to Sony in 2006. Although A mount is now second to E for Sony, by my counting, more autofocus lenses have been produced in A than any other mount, so there are plenty of reasons to want to adapt A-mount lenses... and there are various adapters available -- including the LA-EA1/2/3/4 from Sony itself.

Ok, so why 3D print this one? Because we can seems like a decent answer -- this is an easy print in 2 pieces, the adapter itself and a little locking pin. Certainly, this adapter fits nicely on a Techart Pro LM-EA7 autofocus adapter and uses only about 12g of the 700g drive limit for the LM-EA7. It's great for manual A-mount lenses. The catch is that it doesn't yet incorporate an aperture control for autofocus lenses... which are the vast majority of A-mount lenses. Hopefully, I'll find a good way to implement that soon... but the LA-EA4 adapter already implements aperture control and native autofocus using those lenses on Sony E bodies, and I own an LA-EA4 as well as an LM-EA7.

The last two photos were taken using the LM-EA7 on a Sony A7II, autofocusing a manual-focus Samyang (Opteka) 85mm f/1.4, both shot wide open. In fact, it's the only manual A-mount lens I own. Exceptionally smooth bokeh from that lens, but that super smooth transition to out-of-focus makes it hard to focus manually. By itself, it also has a rather long minimum focus distance, which isn't a problem combining manual focus with autofocus tweaking by the LM-EA7. I think this lens by itself is enough to justify making this adapter, although there are some other great manual lenses in A mount from companies including Samyang and Zeiss.

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

A very straightforward print. I used "dishwasher safe" high-temp black PLA. It should be a little tight, so work a lens in the mount a bit before attaching to a camera -- that way, you can clean any little shards that the flange might cut the first time you fit a lens to it. The bayonet wings are designed to print in the given orientation without supports or post processing. There are three files. Just printing a_20160820.stl will give you the adapter body and two copies of the rather small lens locking pin (one and a spare). Alternatively, the adapter body by itself is a_20160820adapter.stl and a_20160820lockpin.stl is the lens locking pin.

Usage Notes

The M side of the adapter has a dot in the bar-patterned grip portion of the adapter that you align with the M locking pin for mounting and then turn clockwise to lock. To unmount, you simply depress the M mount release lever/tab on the body (or LM-EA7) and turn counter-clockwise, lifting the adapter out when the dot aligns.

The A side of the mount is marked "SONY" on the bottom and "A" on the top. To mount a lens, simply align the red dot on the lens with the dot on the adapter, push the lens in, and turn clockwise until the lens focus mark is at the top. The lens should turn very freely... so now it is time to insert the locking pin. The locking pin fits into the slot at the 3 O'clock position. Although the pin is straight, the slot is actually curved to help seal against light leaks and to hold the pin better, so it might feel tight the first time you put the pin in, and you might have to file your pin a touch if your printer was at all sloppy in making it. You might have to wiggle the lens a bit to perfect the alignment with the pin, but the pin should push in to have the tab nearly flush with the outside of the adapter -- and, more importantly, to rotationally lock the lens so it cannot move. To later remove the lens, you shouldn't need to pull the locking pin all the way out, but merely a couple of mm to rotationally release the lens.

This adapter does not have any aperture-control mechanism, so you can only control the aperture on manual A-mount lenses that have an aperture ring.

title: Qidi Tech Hanging Raspberry Pi and Camera Mount

description.text:
I am using OctoPrint to drive my Qidi Tech I printer and wanted a way to mount my Raspberry Pi and Raspberry Pi camera (v1.3) to the printer. I searched and found a lot of great cases and solutions but none of them quite fit the Qidi Tech and relied on additional materials.

This solution hangs on the left handle - the RPi is exposed on the outside and the camera faces the bed through the glass - both are pressure fit with tight tolerances. The text says OctoPrint and is included as a separate .stl for dual extrusion or optionally including.

If I revisit I would probably make a more universal design to allow for mounting on either side or flipping the RPi to better route the USB and camera cables. I am a novice at design so I welcome any feedback and/or advice on improvements but it fits securely and so far I am very happy with the solution.

Printer:

Qidi Tech I

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

It took a few hours to print - print in supplied orientation (upside down - i.e. hanger on bed plate). I used ABS (slight warping as seen in pics) with a couple of extra perimeters and while it could be stronger, I'm not sure that it really needs to be.

Designed in Sketchup

Collected measurements w/ Digital Caliper
Leveraged RPi specifications from here: http://www.raspberrypi-spy.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2014/07/raspberry_pi_model_b_plus_dimentions.png
Leveraged RPi Camera specifications from here: http://www.recantha.co.uk/blog/wp-content/uploads/2013/05/Raspberry-Pi-Camera-Module-Diagram-853x10242.png

title: Gears of War - " Hammerburst II " Assault Rifle "

description.text:
I did not personally make this 3D model.
You can find the the source file here: http://gamebanana.com/models/3170

I would love to see this modified for cosplay, and made printable.

Inspired by i3PRO feet by strangeagent

Each foot of a MakerFront printer is like a wood scraper. After one of the feet I initially printed broke because a bracket got in the way, I decided to design my own.

My MakerFront i3ProXL printer has 8 feet. 6 feet are normal. 2 feet are different, requiring a wedge cut out for a perpendicular bracket.

A standard sized MakerFront printer as 6 feet. 2 are corner feet. 2 feet are different, requiring a wedge cut out for a perpendicular bracket. 2 are normal feet

I have attached OpenScad code and STL files. The GenericFoot will fit on any foot (except the corner feet of standard size).

Feel free to customize in OpenScad to your taste. All STL files have been tested on the standard and XL model.

Software: Cura
Nozzle: 210

comments.text:
Hallo Mr Fredrik Walldén
Vielen Dank für Ihre Antwort.
In letzter Zeit habe ich drei verschieden Versionen des DJI Inspire gebaut und bin mit keinem der Versionen so richtig zufrieden. Alle haben die gleiche Herausforderung mit der Mechanik des Arme Heben- und Senkens.
Meiner Meinung nach sollte hier ( DJI- Nachbau) der ganze Korpus durch Bauteile aus Aluminium ersetzt werden In Kunststoff mit dem 3D Drucker gefertigte Teile sind zwar sehr steif, aber haben nicht die gewünschte Masse. Druckt man die Teile aber mit 80 % Füllung, so sind sie zu schwer.
So bringt eines meiner Modelle bereits ohne Motore und Elektronik schon 1500 Gramm auf die Waage.
Bei Ihrem Modell ist vermutlich im Zentrum zu wenig Masse vorhanden und damit die Stabilität nicht gegeben die die Arme benötigen.
Mehr Gewicht würde hier vermutlich mehr Dämpfung bedeuten. Oder wie ich vermute, ist der Winkel der Arme zu steil.
Übrigens es freut mich zu sehen, dass es auch noch andere Bastel Werkstätten gibt, die aussehen wie meine.
Beste Grüße
Georgio Ferlini- Austria
comments.author: Georgio

comments.text:
Hallo Leute, Euer Entwurf gefällt mir sehr gut , und ich möchte den Copter auch bauen. Darf ich eine Bitte aussprechen?
Ich kann selbst nicht mit 3-D Software umgehen, daher möchte ich Euch, oder Dich, bitten eine kleine Änderung an diesem Fahrzeug vorzunehmen, oder einfach ein zusätzliches Bauteil zu kreieren.
Uns zwar das Mittelteil " Centermount Mrk3" etwas abzuändern. Der Winkel der abstehenden "Flügel" etwas zurücknehmen, das heißt, etwas flacher legen. Vielleicht nur ca 30 bis 35 Grad!
Weiters habe ich eine Frage; Wie stellt Ihr Euch den Aufbau des "Rumpfes" im inneren des Gehäuses vor.?
Bitte um eine kurze Antwort- Danke

description.text:
Halter für die Y-Welle.
Benötigt wird eine M3 Vierkantmutter!

Ich habe mehrere Varianten erstellt, da es von Drucker zu Drucker
im Ergebniss immer Unterschiede gibt.

Einbaubilder Folgen
This is a SK 20 which is a little improved for a M5 hexagon screw and with nuttrap.
It's a trophy for the winner!

Built on a Makerbot Thing O Matic using 15% infill and 1 extra shell.  Probably would be better with a single shell and faster too.  I modified the original file, moving the bottom inside level up to be parallel to the top.  Otherwise there was shrinkage and cracking in the middle.

comments.text: Just so you know, someone is trying to sell this model as part of their online store. They're called "Top Shelf Gamer" and have recently advertised on Reddit. You may want to let them know in case you do not want them profiting off of your model.

comments.text: I have no problem with the item being distributed/produced, the issue here is that the game itself is likely copyrighted by the manufacturer and if you should decide to profit from it, consider that royalties should be negotiated with them. I don't see where they would mind this trinket from being passed around considering it encourages users to bring onboard more players, sell more games etc. but I'm not a lawyer, not a representative, didn't design the trophy and don't own it. I just made a build for a friend and posted it for the community to enjoy.

I used some M4 35mm screws and some nuts for the assembly.

description.text:
The file ethernet.skp is used to generate the image used here:
https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Twisted_pair_based_ethernet.svg

I have uploaded this file so other can continue my work on the SVG file, if needed.

The model is not yet designed for printing. I was thinking one could make a square transparent tube where the cubes would fit in. There by illustrating how much data bandwidth a give cable bandwidth can handle.

comments.text: Having been around since the days of "thick wire", I hope that the text will make clear that earlier versions of Ethernet used coax rather than twisted pairs.  (I don't go back quite far enough to have had contact with the original "Ethernet" that was used to link campuses at the University of Hawai'i together via RF.  At the time, I was a CS student in the Southwestern U.S.)
comments.author: ArizonaClark

comments.text:

These are 2 adapter plates I made to connect a Greg's Wade's extruder to a Bowden feed tube. You can see in the rendering how I intended to use it. I used to have my p3steel setup with a Bowden configuration as that diagram shows.

Since I've made this I gone from Bowden to direct drive extrusion. I still use this part though for connecting PTFE feed tube from the side of my P3Steel to my direct drive extruder.

Assembly requires a M6 Nut and a quick connect for a PTFE tube. Here is the link to the ones I purchased from amazon.com http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00WE1A3D2/

I posted the full project on github.

http://github.com/CTCHunter1/Bowden-Adapter-Plate

title: US Coin Sorter and Counter Tools

description.text:
Probably should've been doing other things this afternoon but it's raining, work will wait and I just needed something mindless yet arguably productive to do ... like counting up the spare change.

Everybody has a container where you throw your spare change at the end of the day (mine is a metal nautilus received as a Christmas present). But, trivial amounts can add up over time. This design was inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11322, and while I sure that thing works fine, it seemed way too complicated so I cooked the concept down to four essential parts; one for counting, three for sorting.

Throw a hand full of change in the quarter sieve then shake out anything that's not a quarter into a quart Chinese takeout container (also handy for storing this apparatus when not in use). Repeat for the nickel and penny and you'll eventually end up with just a pile of dimes. Go with smaller handfuls of dimes and pennies because their diameters are so similar. Overall the process is pretty quick. Once they're separated just load them into the counter then the wrappers.

A note about the counter, Z-axis calibrations vary so you definitely want to manually count the first time through. Once you know exactly where 40 or 50 count falls on your print just mark it with a Sharpie if it's not perfect and you think you might forget what the sweet spot looks like.

I've included the STEP and Rhino files in case anyone has a need to remix this for other currencies.

This adapter fixes the difference in height of the cable chain between the printer frame and the extruder which inhibits the cable chain to flex easily.
I printed this in Formfutura Carbonfill.
The holes are 3 mm and 2.5 mm. I cut thread in the small holes for the m3 screws.
The screws to mount the cable chain bracket are the stock screws. The screws to mount the adapter itself are the screws of the front mounted cooler (I use http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1090433).

After I made this, I found a great solution for this problem by rasarmg: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1432064. See also the desgns mentioned there.

title: One piece articulated robot keychain with a clip

description.text:
This is the big brother of my 10 minutes robot, I wanted to make a keychain robot with a clasp embedded into it's head.

The end result is very nice but just a little too big to be a pocketable keychain.

I had to use supports or a brim with this model because the shoulders have a tiny buildplate connection area and wouldn't print without something holding them.

I printed in PLA, with support, 0.2mm layer height, 1.2mm shell, no infill.

The clasp is a "Lobster Swivel Clasps for Key Ring 37x16mm" from AliExpress, to insert it into the robot you need to stop the print at height 5.2mm (I used Cura's "Pause at height" plugin) insert the clasp making sure the ring isn't higher then the printed part and resume the print.

Designed with SketchUp, STL cleaned with Microsoft 3D Builder, sliced with Cura and printed on my Robo3D R1+ (I've added a "RepRap Discount Full Graphic Smart Controller" to my printer, pausing and resuming won't work on a stock Robo3D R1+ because you need on-printer controls to resume)

Update the V2 file makes the back of the knees and sholders flat, it isn't as nice as the rounded version but it has larger printbed surface area and is easier to print.

title: X Belt tensioner for Tevo Tarantula

description.text:
The design
Since my Y belt tensioner worked out so good I decided to make a belt tensioner for the X axis. It works the same as the Y belt tensioner and has a similar design. I've tested it and it works perfectly.

There's also a X motor mount to go with this
X motor mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1730523
Y belt tensioner: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1704100
Y motor mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1704123

What you need
Use everything from the old bracket. The extra you need is:
10x M4x10
10x M4 T-nut
1x M4x40 screw
1x M4 Nut
1x M4 washer (optional)

How to install
Mount and install the same way the old bracket is installed. The pulleys are installed into the mechanism without the lock washer and the nut. Use only the screw and the lock nut.

M4x40 goes through the mechanism and the backplate.
M4 Nut is pressed into the turnwheel.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

title: Circular Tiered Tool Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Keep your project work space organized with this circular type tiered tool holder.

Add an optional Lazy Susan bearing for a smoother rotation.

The Autodesk Fusion 360 file (.f3d) is a fully parameterized model where you can adjust everything in the model including all hole sized, layer diameters and layer heights. (Layer heights are based on the golden ration and you need only modify the first layer height and the others will follow.)

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

5%

Notes:

Used ESUN PLA+ 1.75 filament. I would not recommend ABS due to warping and splitting factors.

Use at least 5 layers for the bottom and top layers (this gives strength for the pointy ends of tools hitting the bottom of the holes as well as provides for structure for the lazysusan bearing mount screws.

Side layers can be 3 or 4 layers.

Optional Lazy Susan bearing installation

I purchased a Lazy Susan bearing from Amazon.
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00IK4OOW8/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

However, any like bearing should work.

To install this one.

  1. Find the center and draw a diagonal line across the base.

  2. Draw a perpendicular line through the center.

  3. Place the bearing on the base so the mounting holes align with the lines you drew. This will center the bearing on the base.

  4. Drill four mounting holes in the base to accept the mounting screws. (the five layers should provide sufficient holding power for the screws.)

  5. Add a small washer as a spacer between the base and bearing at each mounting point then screw the bearing to the base. (This allows enough distance between the bearing and the base to allow the bearing to work.)

  6. Turn over and load your tools.

With the tools loaded, there should be enough weight to allow the tool holder to spin easily without wandering. If it does, use a high friction pad (a silicone mat or rubber router pad) to provide additional friction.

Autodesk Fusion 360

If you have Autodesk Fusion 360, the Circular Tool Holder(F360).f3d file has parameters to define

Layer1Dia - the base diameter. Subsequent diameters are based upon this value along with the layer hole diameter and margin.

Layer1Hole - the diameter of the first layer holes

Height - the height of the first layer. Subsequent layers are based upon this value and the golden ratio.

Margin - added to the Layer1Hole value to give an additional margin around the hole.

Layer1NumHoles - the number of holes around the first layer.

Layer1Depth - the depth of each hole. Subsequent layer depths are base on the layer height and previous layer heights.

If modifying the layer diameters, sometimes the layer holes will merge. To fix this modify the LayerxNumHoles.

Of course, you can modify any and all parameters to your heart's desire.

title: Samsung SmartThings Multipurpose Sensor spacer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've been frustrated several times mounting a Samsung SmartThings Multipurpose Sensor as a door open/close indicator because some doors have a large offset between the door and the door frame.

You can mount your Multipurpose Sensor directly to this thing, which provides an 8mm positive offset. This is useful, for example, on sliding doors. The stock mount provides only a 2mm positive offset.

The stock mount is also hollow on the back, which makes it hard to mount with anything besides screws. I've left off screw holes and provide a flat back so you can get a nice mating surface for 3M Command Strips (size Medium is a perfect fit).

There's two files:
1) Provides a rounded interior. This looks better, but Tinkercad seems to generate slightly odd STLs in this case and results in strange slicing. Be sure to check out the sliced layer view in your slicer. I printed it and it works great, it's just not ideal as it creates some interior walls that should be fill.
2) Provides a squared-off interior (exterior is still rounded). This model is much more solid, but doesn't look quite as finished. Might good as a base for further modifications, but #1 served my needs so I didn't take it any further.

If you need less offset than 8mm, sink the print into the bed using your slicer.

Printer:

Monoprice MP Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Notes:

No supports required. The tabs have 45* angles and should print fine in PLA, at least.

title: Dyson DC41 Canister Release Button (top piece)

description.text:
Updated... Added more support around the points on the piece that are stressed the most when the vacuum is carried by the canister handle.

I have a Dyson DC41 Animal vacuum cleaner. I like it because I have 2 dogs and it works great on dog hair. However, the plastic piece used as the release button for the canister, has broken twice. That little plastic part is sold in the UK, but not as easily available in the US (though you can find it on EBay for about $16). The first time this broke on me, I ended up buying a whole new canister for $50+.

I decided to try my hand an modeling a replacement myself using OpenJSCAD, and this is what I came up with. I tried to make the area of the top section of the piece (where the breaks occurred on the original part) a little more robust.

This may also work for the DC43 as well, but I don't have that model to verify that.

Lastly, I found out the part is a little different for some - thanks to NovaCaine's remix (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2466123), so if you need the part that has the bottom pin built-in, you can use his model.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Due to the stresses put on this part during normal use, it is best to have this oriented on its side. You can use ABS or PLA - though ABS might be a better choice for strength.

Note that because of the complexity of this part and the way in which is should be oriented for printing, there will be a lot of support material. It is admittedly a pain to deal with and care must be taken when removing it.

description.text: The Sega Saturn Video game console has a small door on the back where the backup battery is located. this door also covers up the expansion slot for the VCD player. One of my Sega Saturn consoles was missing this door so I've designed a replacement.

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200 micron

Notes:

I recommend printing in ABS and printing on the thin side with supports and a brim to help with stability. There's no good "flat side" for the build platform but printing on the side like this will offer the most strength in the tab anyway since it will stress perpendicular to the layers.

I've included an alternate model with custom supports for FDM printers, if you use this then you'll want to DISABLE supports in your slicer. the gap on these supports is 0.32mm which should be good for printers with 0.4mm nozzles.

title: Z stop Adjuster  - Max Micron (Prusa i3 clones)

description.text:
this is a Z stop adjuster for the Max Micron Prusa i3 Clone and other 20mm aluminum extruded framed printers.

Works well, actually better than planned
You'll need one of the extra M5 screws and the twist mount thing to hold to frame.
you'll also need a M4 round head and nut.

Please Note -

1 - you do NEED to lightly file/sand the joint, it's a tad tight on purpose as you want it to move freely but not bobble and everyone's printers are lightly different so depending on your print it will vary how much sanding or filing (I highly recommend getting files, so much better for this purpose than sand paper)
Be careful NOT to file or sand the lip off inside the arm, this holds it in place!

2 - Crazy glue the cap and the little nut in place so they stay and don't shift.

3 - suggest printing at 0.1 or higher layer resolution for best results and fit.

Parts
  • The printed objects from this project
  • An 8cm x 8cm computer cooler fan
  • Female panel mount DC power jack
  • Male DC power jack
  • 12V DC power supply (see the power consumption of the fan to define its characteristics)
  • DC power switch
  • Green/yellow cleaning sponge (to get the "filter" from)
  • Zipties (I needed 2)
Assembly

1) Make 2 holes on the box of the bottom part: one for the female power jack, other for the switch
2) Put the cooler on the bottom part
3) Put the top part over the cooler
4) Tie the top and bottom using some zipties
5) Solder the wires on the female power jack / switch
6) Solder the Male power jack on the power supply 12V wires
7) Install the switch and the female power

description.text:
This is a simple guard that reduces the entrance size of any conventional hive. It can help protect from mice or inter-hive competitors, etc.

I have a smaller Printrbot Simple Metal, so the full length (15.25") wouldn't fit on the board so I divided it up into 3 sub-6" pieces that can be easily and seamlessly be connected.

The guard can also be rotated so that nothing can enter or exit (when you need to move a hive/work on or around it). This is facilitated by the separate connector plates (x2) that you can screw into the hive. The guard then just slides in.

So far it has worked very well on the hive. Honey bees are able to pass easily in and out of the hive.

Feel free to let me know if you have issues or questions!

When you get down to really designing useful things to be 3D printed with plastic, you get to a point where you need to start considering material properties. Plastics have an extensive range of tensile strength, hardness, modulus of elasticity, and dozens of other material properties. A couple of the classic engineering tests are tensile strength break test and a compression strength break test. In this project we will do some material testing.
https://youtu.be/4dgdBdbmbTE

Printer:

Generic Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I did 100% infill for the parts I printed, 30-40% infill should be fine. Remember you want the part that will be broken to be solid, so adjust your shell thickness to make that part solid.
I printed on several different printers
Prusa was PETG, Fabrikator had ABS loaded, and a Replicator had Makerbot PLA.

I came up with some properties I wanted to test for. Next I looked up some preliminary numbers on different plastics I was using.
In my photos/videos:
Black = PETG
Blue = ABS
Clear = PLA
I designed the pieces with a cross section that should be able to be broken within the range of my spring scale. I also took into consideration that I desired the pieces to break in a relatively concentrated location on each piece.

Loaded up Fusion 360 and sketched out some cross sections. The large breakers are present in the thing files in case you have some professional breaking gear like you would find in a university materials science lab.
NGSS CCSS

Materials strength is key to designing parts that will take stress. This was particularly interesting to me because I have already designed some 3D printed parts that failed spectacularly. See Photo Below To get a practical appreciation for the strength of the materials you are using, a student can participate in pushing some materials to the limit through testing the material to the failure limit. Objectives
  • Learn how to calculate cross sectional area.
  • Learn what materials properties are (e.g. tensile strength, modulus of elasticity, compressive strength, etc...)
  • Learn how materials strength works hand in hand with design loads for a finished product.
  • Learn how to test and calculate material strength.
    • Audience Main application: STEM of all ages, High school physics, college physics lab, materials science, engineering. Really any age could benefit from this project. The demonstration could enlighten all ages. Standards MP.4 - Model with mathematics. (HS-ETS1-1), (HS-ETS1-2), (HS-ETS1-3), (HS-ETS1-4)
    RST.11-12.9 - Synthesize information from a range of sources (e.g., texts, experiments, simulations) into a coherent understanding of a process, phenomenon, or concept, resolving conflicting information when possible.

Step 1 - Background and Knowledge
  • Discuss materials science and property of materials.
  • Discuss / review the cross sections and how to calculate their area.
  • Discuss how the breaking tests work to show real world material properties.
  • Print and use one ore more of the pieces for as a visualization aid.
  • Using published material properties for materials you are 3D printing, develop an estimated break strength for pieces that you have as visual aides.
    • Step 2 - Design and/or build Option 1:
  • Have students design a piece to break and print it.
    • Option 2:
  • Print the pieces thing files.
    • Step 3 - Practical testing Option 1:
  • Weigh all the pieces and measure them, record results.
  • Assemble the breaking setup.
    The piece to be broke needs to be anchored to a secure place, if breaking the point load piece, it requires the anchor to have less strength to resist the test. If breaking the bigger pieces you will need an anchor with more resistance strength - I used a agricultural disc or harrow for my anchor
    Anchor -> breaking piece <- spring scale -- for the tensile breakers
    Anchor -> breaking piece <- Anchor with the spring scale hooked on the breaker in the middle (see video) -- for the point load piece
  • Setup any cameras or have students get ready.
  • Start the test by pulling the scale in a controlled manner.
  • If you witness or your scale kept the break stress, write it down.
  • measure and record the dimensions of the break point, in case there were printing anomalies that created a reduced section (weak point?).
  • Break all the pieces in the same manner.
    • Option 2:
  • Print several of the breakers with differing print properties, such as layer resolution, infill, extrusion speed, quality, etc..
  • Print in different materials.
  • Configure a piece of fresh off the roll filament for breaking.
  • The proceed above breaking them in control groups.
    • Option 3 (addon):
  • Inspect the breaks for elongation, and other stress damage. Measure, quantify, and record it.
    • Step 4 - Calculations
  • Calculate the cross section of each break.
  • Calculate the material strength for each break .
  • Calculate the average strength of the material broken.
  • If you printed with different properties, aggregate the data and have students plot it out.
    • Step 5 - Review
  • Compare and contrast your strength results to published numbers for the plastics you used.
  • Discuss why we got the results we got.
  • Discuss how students think they could use the results to design 3D printed objects.
  • Compare and contrast all the results if you printed with different properties and/or materials. Why would we use different plastics?
    • Tips and Tricks
  • Print several breakers, average the results
  • Use a scale with some head room for the break strength.

Accessories The following materials and items can be helpful with this project.
  • Metal rod (I used a screw driver in the video) for securing one end of the piece
  • Clamps. I used a C clamp and a vise grip
  • Spring scale with capacity greater than the estimated break strength (example: https://www.amazon.com/Electronic-Balance-Digital-Fishing-Hanging/dp/B00B301MPI/)
  • Optional: professional breaking setup
  • Optional: mechanical or electric winch to provide smooth pulling
  • Camera - to record the numbers in a non-pro setup such as mine.
  • Paper and pencil to record results
  • Scale - for calculating density
  • calipers, rule, or tape to measure the broken cross section
  • protection gear - eye protection!! and any other gear that might be a good idea.

Small breaker in ABS, captured the frame before it broke. Small breaker in PLA, captured the frame before it broke. Large breaker in PETG, captured the frame before it broke. An example of point load strength tests with affordable equipment. ABS point load breaker, the frame before it broke. PLA point load breaker, the frame before it broke.

comments.text: if you print at 70% what ever part, then coat in graphene Nano platelets 30%(amazon)  and epoxy resin 70% (home depot, Lowes) then coat with very thick coat (whole part) and then place in a plastic vacuum bag and using a vacuum food saver you can force the graphene resin into the part. The dry, finish with three more coats outer and inner layers and now you have a 100 x's stronger product that is both e.m.p. proof and radiation proof, providing you have covered 100% of your part.. Vacuum forcing the resin into the part is very important. Also, then when finished glaze with a coat (whole part) in just epoxy resin by itself, polish and your done. A little extra work will get 'er done! Then retest to see your new results you'll be amazed.

description.text:
Many young scouts around the world build derby cars. In the United States, Cub Scouts race them every year. I designed a car to be printed that would have taken quite a bit longer to make out of wood, and it would have been quite difficult. This project encourages out of the box thinking to create your own derby racer.
https://youtu.be/2gBLHi5XOog

Printer:

HK Fabrikator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed with a wood filament I got from China. The heating and cooling cycle gave a pretty amazing wood grain look to the final print. The first print I made, came out so awesome, I never tried to print it in another material.

Stock block, nail axels, plastic wheels, numbers, and some breif instructions from an official kit

I started out with a standard pinewood derby kit which has a block of wood, and some general car specifications: overall width 2-3/4", overall length 7", width between wheels 1-3/4", bottom clearance to track 3/8"

Many race runners provide an extensive list of additional rules to comply with.

I took measurements on the block.

Notes on my derby design from my engineering notebook.

I loaded up fusion 360 and sketched up the block. Then I marked out where my wheels would go and got a rough idea of how much material I would need to hold my axle nails.

I then switched to a view where I drew a half profile of the cone, then rotated it around a central axis to generate the cone.

Finally I had to model up the connections between the axle holders and the cone.

Then on to printing.

A few hours into the 13 hour print.

Thousands of young scouts build derby cars and race them every year. 3D printing a car within the rules, brings about different ideas that are not easily made with traditional woodworking techniques.  This project is to demonstrate at least 1 complex shape that is easier to construct with 3D printing as compared with traditional wood working. The derby construction and racing itself is filled with all sorts of STEM related topics that work together to get you the fastest car down the track.

• Learn how 3D printing enables designs that were previously hard to obtain.
  • Learn the mechanics involved in racing a derby car.
  • Race a car you designed and printed!

• MP.4 - Model with mathematics. (HS-ETS1-1), (HS-ETS1-2), (HS-ETS1-3), (HS-ETS1-4)
  • RST.11-12.9 - Synthesize information from a range of sources (e.g., texts, experiments, simulations) into a coherent understanding of a process, phenomenon, or concept, resolving conflicting information when possible.

Step 1 - Background Knowledg
  • Discuss the physics of a derby car.
  • Discuss friction.
  • Discuss how 3D printing unlocks new and imaginative designs that were previously difficult.
  • Print and use one ore more of the pieces for as a visualization aid.
  • Decide on race rules, so that everyone has the same rules to design/build under.
    • Step 2 - Design and/or build Option 1:
  • Have students design a car and print it.
    • Option 2:
  • Print the car in the thing files.
    • Option 3:
  • Print the entire car, wheels and all
    • Option 4:
  • Develop an incremental design, where small things are changed in each iteration to find out which properties are most important in derby car design.
    • Step 3 - Practical testing Option 1:
  • Assemble cars
  • Setup a track
  • Run the cars on the track
    • Option 2:
  • Assemble cars
  • Run a different type of contest with the cars
    • Step 3 - Calculations
  • Average the heats to determine the car with the fastest
  • Calculate the fastest car
  • Calculate the fastest lane
  • Calculate the speed
  • If you printed with different properties, aggregate the data and have students plot it out looking for results from the incremental changes.
    • Step 4 - Review
  • Compare and contrast the race results with the designs
  • Discuss why we got the results we got.
  • Discuss how students think they could use the results to design a different car.

The following materials and items can be helpful with this project.
  • Pinewood derby kit - sold at scout shops and craft stores
  • Calipers, rule, or tape to measure or layout with
  • Multi lane track to race on
  • Weights - washers, sinkers, pipe soldering lead, tungsten, etc.
  • Scale
  • Graphite
  • Sand paper
  • Paint
  • calipers, rule, or tape to measure the broken cross section
  • protection gear - eye protection!! and any other gear that might be a good idea.

• What is friction?
  • How does potential energy convert into kinetic energy?
  • How fast did the cars go?
  • What was the most influential design parameter on final outcome?

• http://pinewoodphysics.com/index.html
  • https://www.wired.com/2010/12/pinewood-derby-physics/
  • See Mark Rober's Youtube video below - science of pinewood derby
    • A quick video of the printed funnel car running. Pack 146's 2016 Derby Race Mark Rober's Video on Pinewood Derby Cars

So I'm at MS&T and realized that it takes SO long to open a drawer. So I made a mount so I would never have to open a drawer to get my trusty dial caliper ever again.

Steps:

Step 1: Measure the bed's bar (turns out to be 3.6 inches)
Step 2: Make a rectangle with two arcs perpendicular to it and extrude it to the desired width of the inner slot + 1/8th of an inch (or twice however thick you want slot's walls to be).
Step 3: Make the slots. The way I made mine was to do a symmetric extrusion and then a symmetric cut.
Step 4: Fillet stuff so it will naturally go in the slot even if you don't place it in 100% correctly.

author: tamberg

description.text:
This is a basic foot for 1/2" PVC pipe, to turn it into a cheap, easy to make spool holder.

What's awesome about this spool holder is that the length of the upper pipe can be cut to any length, so that you can hold as many spools as your heart desires!

The feet have a diameter of about 147 mm, so it can be printed on a Printrbot with no brim/raft or large prep circles. The design leaves a little bit of wiggle room for the PVC, but the PVC will stand straight nonetheless.
I have about 6 spools on my holder, totaling out to about 4.2 kg (9.25 lbs)

This flange-shaped foot doesn't necessarily need to be used for a spool holder... It could be used universally to attach PVC to walls/tables/etc.
Feel free to modify the design files however you like!

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Simple Black

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm layer height

Infill:

15-25%

Notes:

2 shells seem to work out pretty well.
Printed mine at 205 °C with a bed temp of 55 °C

-PVC Spool Holder Foot (x2)
-1/2" PVC pipe (any length)
-1/2" PVC right-angle adapter (x2)
-Hacksaw or PVC cutters

-Hacksaw guide (optional)
-Spray Paint (optional)

After you print out the feet, you're going to have to cut out the holder's legs and center bar.

Legs:
The legs of this assembly should be identical in size.
Cut out two lengths of PVC that will leave room for your spools to spin freely. I cut mine to about 8 inches, which left a substantial amount of space for various types of spools.

Center Bar:
For the center bar, place your spools together and measure them from point to point. Add about 2 inches to this measurement and cut. The extra two inches are to leave space to attach the right angle adapters, and leaves some space for the spools to move if they need to.

Assemble!
Attach the right-angle adapters to the legs you cut out.
insert the center bar into the other side of one of the adapters, and slide your spools onto the assembly.
Make sure that the filament is available on the side of your choice (whether you typically feed from the bottom of the spool or from the top).
On the other side of the bar, attach the right angle adapter and other leg.
Make sure that the legs are parallel and straight, and insert them into the feet.

You're done!

title: RepRap Huxley hot end tube deflector

description.text:
I was having a problem with my Huxley PTFE hot end tube snagging on one of the support brackets for the controller board. I came up with this easy add-on deflector that solved my problem.   
You remove the mounting screw and slide the deflector over the bottom half of the PCB support. You then reinstall the screw. The deflector prevents the PTFE tube from snagging on the support or the screw used to clamp the support.  
I have 4 Huxley 3D printers and have now modified all of them.
I used Autodesk Inventor Pro 2011 to design the piece.

title: Logitech G105 Gaming Keyboard Extra Long Stands

description.text:
As mentioned by a lot of people, the Logitech G105 Backlit Gaming Keyboard has been noted as being a relatively flat keyboard. The keyboard does come with standard stands to raise it up a little bit, but I created stands that fit the keyboard itself just fine and don't interfere with the keyboard's original design. Instead I took advantage of the extra space conveniently left by Logitech to add height to the stands.

Instructions:

  1. Remove current stands by folding down and pinching while pulling out of keyboard.
  2. Insert new stands just as the originals came out.

author: RK721

print_settings.Notes:: I printed in PLA with 60% infill and it seems sturdy enough.  Print with support for the bearing  holders and the mounting screws.

description.text:
Rotating Collet Rack for R8 collets. Holds 8 collets.

Requires 2 bearings, bolt, nut, and washer to complete.

This is similar to little machine shop Part Number: 5001, except this one only holds 8 collets.

https://youtu.be/aCxWUNvItQw

11/2/2017
11 position holder added. This only requires one bearing.
https://youtu.be/VnkOA6mjVqs

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

60%

Notes:

I printed in PLA with 60% infill and it seems sturdy enough. Print with support for the bearing holders and the mounting screws.

I reamed out the axle hole with an undersized 1/4" reamer. A drill bit will work just as well.

I used 2 bearings. They are 3/4"OD, 1/4" ID, 5/16" tall.
One bolt is needed. I used a 2" long 1/4" socket head cap screw.
One washer is used between the two printed pieces.
A nut is used on the top to hold it together.

If your bolt head interferes with the bearings you will need another washer and a longer bolt.

I placed some loctite on the nut to keep it in place.

11/2/17
11 position rack was printed in ABS.
This one spins more freely. There is no washer between the top and bottom piece. I used a washer between the bottom piece and the nut.
